name: Alberta
popup: Data on IBD hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 (Temporal Trends in IBD Hospitalization rates from 2002 to 2018 in Alberta, Canada: A Population-Based Cohort Study.) which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002â€“2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for IBD in Alberta was 21.81/100,000, which was significantly lower than 38.18/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -3.01; 95% CI: -3.38, -2.64). This is an extension of the data found in Coward 2019 which provides results from 2002â€“2015. In 2015, the primary hospitalization rate for IBD was 22.59/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 40.31/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -3.40; 95% CI: -3.98, -2.81).
appendixF_popup:
Data on IBD hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 (Temporal Trends in IBD Hospitalization rates from 2002 to 2018 in Alberta, Canada: A Population-Based Cohort Study) which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002Ð2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for IBD in Alberta was 4.02/100 IBD patients, which was significantly lower than 13.09/100 IBD patients in 2002 (AAPC: -6.65; 95% CI: -7.48, -5.82). In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for IBD was 16.72/100 IBD patients which had also decreased significantly from 36.57/100 IBD patients in 2002 (AAPC: -4.18; 95% CI: -4.69, -3.66) (Buie 2022).

Data on CD hospitalizations come from Buie 2022, which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002Ð2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for CD in Alberta was 4.60/100 CD patients, which was significantly lower than 14.54/100 CD patients in 2002 (AAPC: -6.54; 95% CI: -7.33, -5.75). In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for CD was 18.41/100 CD patients which had decreased significantly from 40.44/100 CD patients in 2002 (AAPC: -4.06; 95% CI: -4.56, -3.55) (Buie 2022).

Data on UC hospitalizations come from Buie 2022, which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002Ð2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for UC in Alberta was 4.49/100UC patients, which was also significantly lower than 12.68/100 UC patients in 2002 (AAPC: -5.71; 95% CI: -6.91, -4.50). In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for UC was 15.56/100 UC patients which was significantly lower than 30.83/100 UC patients in 2002 (AAPC: -3.66; 95% CI: -4.38, -2.93) (Buie 2022).

name: Alberta
popup: Data on CD hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 (Temporal Trends in IBD Hospitalization rates from 2002 to 2018 in Alberta, Canada: A Population-Based Cohort Study.) which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002â€“2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for CD in Alberta was 12.46/100,000, which was significantly lower than 26.09/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -4.12; 95% CI: -4.48, -3.76). Additionally, Coward 2019 reports rates spanning 2002â€“2015. In 2015, the hospitalization rate for primary CD discharges was 12.99/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 28.20/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -4.62; 95% CI: -5.21, -4.03).

name: Alberta
popup: Data on UC hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 (Temporal Trends in IBD Hospitalization rates from 2002 to 2018 in Alberta, Canada: A Population-Based Cohort Study.) which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002â€“2018. In 2018, the primary hospitalization rate for UC in Alberta was 8.87/100,000, which was not significantly lower than 11.04/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -0.73; 95% CI: -1.48, -0.02). Additionally, Coward 2019 reports rates spanning 2002â€“2015. In 2015, the hospitalization rate for primary UC discharges was 8.96/100,000, which had not significantly decreased from 11.12/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -0.74; 95% CI: -1.81, 0.34).

name: Alberta
popup: Data on IBD hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 (Temporal Trends in IBD Hospitalization rates from 2002 to 2018 in Alberta, Canada: A Population-Based Cohort Study.) which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002â€“2018. In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for IBD was 142.18/100,000 which significantly increased from 110.65/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: 1.56; 95% CI: 1.32, 1.80) (Buie 2022). Additionally, in 2015, the secondary hospitalization rate for IBD in Alberta was 57.89/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 83.88/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -1.98; 95% CI: -2.42, -1.49) (Coward 2019).

name: Alberta
popup: Data on CD hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 (Temporal Trends in IBD Hospitalization rates from 2002 to 2018 in Alberta, Canada: A Population-Based Cohort Study.) which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002â€“2018. In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for CD was 73.11/100,000 which significantly increased from 72.18/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: 0.42; 95% CI: 0.11, 0.72) (Buie 2022). Additionally, in 2015, the hospitalization rate for secondary CD discharges was 38.94/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 60.29/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -2.32; 95% CI: -2.84, -1.79) (Coward 2019).

name: Alberta
popup: Data on UC hospitalizations come from Buie 2022 (Temporal Trends in IBD Hospitalization rates from 2002 to 2018 in Alberta, Canada: A Population-Based Cohort Study.) which provides rates for primary and all cause discharges between 2002â€“2018. In 2018, the all cause hospitalization rate for UC was 51.27/100,000 which significantly increased from 28.71/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: 3.29; 95% CI: 2.94, 3.63) (Buie 2022). Additionally, in 2015, the hospitalization rate for secondary UC discharges was 17.44/100,000, which had not significantly decreased from 20.49/100,000 in 2002 (AAPC: -0.66; 95% CI: -1.36, 0.05) (Coward 2019).

popup: Data on IBD hospitalizations come from the OECD (King 2019), which provides rates for primary discharges spanning 2000â€“2015. name: Germany
popup: Data on CD hospitalizations come from Stallmach 2015, which provides rates for primary discharges spanning 2000â€“2012 and Stoss 2021 which provides rates for primary diagnoses spanning 2010-2017. In 2012, the hospitalization rate for CD was 24.7/100,000, which had significantly increased from 22.5/100,000 in 2000 (AAPC: 0.78; 95% CI: 0.14, 1.42) (Stallmach 2015). While the hospitalization rate was 28.49/100,000 in 2010 and 31.54/100,000 in 2017, the rate decreased significantly overall (AAPC: -3.41; 95% CI: -4.63,-2.18) (Stoss 2021). Additionally, the CD primary diagnosis hospitalization rate in 2000 was estimated at 26.4/100,000 (Sonnenberg 2010).

Additionally, the UC primary diagnosis hospitalization rate in 2000 was estimated at 19.2/100,000 (Sonnenberg 2010).

name: Poland
popup: Data on IBD hospitalizations come from the OECD (King 2019), which provides rates for primary discharges spanning 2003â€“2015. name: Catalonia
popup: Brunet 2020 provides CD hospitalization rates for Catalonia spanning 2011-2017. In 2017, the primary discharge rate was 14.83/100,000 which had significantly increased from 10.55/100,000 in 2011 (AAPC: 5.34; 95% CI 4.07, 6.62).
appendixF_popup: Brunet 2020 provides CD hospitalization rates for Catalonia spanning 2011-2017. In 2017, the primary discharge rate was 7.22/100 CD patients which had significantly decreased from 9.27/100 CD patients in 2011 (AAPC: -4.38; 95% CI -5.50, -3.25). However, the all-cause discharge rate significantly increased between 2011 (27.28/100 CD patients) and 2017 (29.16/100 CD patients) (AAPC: 1.57; 95% CI: 0.55, 2.61).

name: Catalonia
popup: Brunet 2020 provides CD hospitalization rates for Catalonia spanning 2011-2017. The all-cause discharge rate significantly incrased between 2011 (31.06/100,000) and 2017 (59.92/100,000) (AAPC: 11.90; 95% CI: 10.89, 12.93).

name: United States
popup:
Data on IBD hospitalizations come from 19 studies using estimated national data and spanning 1998â€“2018. A subset of these studies provide enough data for temporal analysis. A recent study showed the primary discharge rate to increase significantly from 27.05/100,000 in 2005, to 29.71/100,000 in 2016 (AAPC: 0.68; 95% CI: 0.06, 1.31) (Ma 2020).

See also: Nguyen 2007, Ananthakrishnan 2008, Ananthakrishnan 2011a, Sridhar 2011, Barnes 2016, Marchioni 2017, Barber 2018, Cohen-Mekelburg 2018, Ramos-Rodriguez 2018, Rezapour 2018, Dalal 2019, Galoosian 2009, Dahiya 2021, Ding 2021

name: United States
popup:
Data on CD hospitalizations come from 29 studies using estimated national data and spanning 1990â€“2018. A subset of these studies provide enough data for temporal analysis. According to Kichloo 2021, in 2018, the CD hospitalization rate for primary discharges was 17.30/100,000, which had significantly decreased from 19.24/100,000 in 2008 (AAPC: -0.76; 95% CI: -1.23, -0.30).

See also: Bewtra 2007, Nguyen 2007, Sonnenberg 2009, Nguyen 2010, Ananthakrishnan 2011a, Sridhar 2011, Geltzeiler 2014, Barnes 2016, Stein 2016, Wadhwa 2016, Limketkai 2017, Malarcher 2017, Marchioni 2017, Sharma 2017, Barber 2018, Ramos-Rodriguez 2018, Rezapour 2018, Dalal 2019, Galoosian 2009, Xu 2019, Peery 2019, Schwartz 2020

name: United States
popup:
Data on UC hospitalizations come from 25 studies using estimated national data and spanning 1990â€“2018. A subset of these studies provide enough data for temporal analysis. According to Kichloo 2021, the UC hospitalization rate for primary discharges was 11.23/100,000 in 2008, which decreased non-significantly to 10.87/100,000 in 2018 (AAPC: -0.04; 95% CI: -0.52, 0.45).

See also: Bewtra 2007, Nguyen 2007, Sonnenberg 2009, Ananthakrishnan 2010, Nguyen 2010, Ananthakrishnan 2011a, Sridhar 2011, Geltzeiler 2014, Barnes 2016, Marchioni 2017, Poojary 2017, Sharma 2017, Barber 2018, Ramos-Rodriguez 2018, Rezapour 2018, Dalal 2019, Galoosian 2009, Peery 2019, Schwartz 2020, Olaiya 2021

name: United States

See also: Nguyen 2007, Ananthakrishnan 2008, Ananthakrishnan 2011a, Sridhar 2011, Barnes 2016, Marchioni 2017, Barber 2018, Cohen-Mekelburg 2018, Ramos-Rodriguez 2018, Rezapour 2018, Dalal 2019, Galoosian 2009, Dahiya 2021, Ding 2021
